member.name: A:Tools.Runtime.CompilerServices.dll
member.summary: Defines custom attributes for assembly postrpocessing.

remarks.para: DLL, Any CPU, Strong Named, Standard Versioning, Managed, VB
This assembly does not contain actual postrocessing code. It's contained in AssemblyPostprocessor.exe.

This library does not depend on core Tools.dll, so you can use it without having big Tools.dll as reference. Further more, if your posprocessing is designed certain way you can instruct AssemblyPostrpocessor to remove reference to Tools.Runtime.CompilerServices as well.

member.name: A:Tools.SqlServer.dll
member.summary: Contains managed code to be invoked on server-side of Microsft SQL Server. Contains various utility functions to be called from Transact-SQL.

remarks.para: DLL, Any CPU, Strong Named, Standard Versioning, Managed, VB
Load this assembly to SQL server and setup CLI stored procedures. This DLL is not intentended to become your reference unless you are developing a DL that will also be uploaded to SQL Server.

member.version: The assembly is now strongly named.

member.name: A:Tools.Win.dll
member.summary: Contains managed wrappers around various Win32 APIs.

member.name: A:Tools.Windows.dll
member.summary: Contains WinForms and WPF functionality

remarks.para: DLL, Any CPU, Strong Named, Standard Versioning, Managed, VB

This assembly will likely be split to 3 assemblies in future (Tools.Windows.Forms, Tools.Windows.WPF, and Tools.Windows.Interop and maybe Tools.Windows.Common). This will likely introduce breaking changes to API.
